Yesterday was flat out humiliating, but worth it. Today, I feel more humbled than humiliated. Two days in, and I feel twice as better than when I started. But that's like saying I improved from 5% to 10%, and that's the humbling part. I have so much more "quieting" to do internally. I'm still very conscious of how long 40 minutes is out of my day, still mindful of all the things I keep going over, that I should be tuning out and focusing on just yoga. My mind is still busy and pre-occupied/distracted by all the noise of my daily life. My breathing is surprisingly counter-intuitive, and struggling to find aerobic synchronicity with Adriene's instructions. I can already tell that this journey will be worth it, that all the things I am becoming aware of are things I do need to address. It's still daunting that the journey itself is not going to be quick or easy. I feel like the fat kid's second day at the gym, or the crippled's second day in rehabilitation. I know this is necessary, I'm willing to show up, just a bit humbled by how much showing up I'm going to have to do to get there. This is counter-intuitive to my natural tendency of just "plowing through it." I can't just knock this out in a few hours or binge all the episodes in a day. It will literally be just one day at a time. But it is necessary. Today, like yesterday, I've got to take what I've learned, and consciously apply it throughout my day. Just like yesterday. Just like tomorrow. And all the days that lie ahead. Until it's not so conscious, til it's reflexive.

One day, I will be bragging about this journey. One day, everyone will notice the difference. One day, I'll be talking with someone who is where I am at right now, and convincing them that it's totally worth sticking to. But that day will never come if I don't stick with it all the way through. So today, I'm eating a lot of humble pie, and I'm going to #JustKeepSwimming swimming swimming.

I always imagine that my fingers are like that of a ghecko (the lizard) and my fingerprints are like mini-grips (the imagery helps a little so I pay attention). So wide fingers with extra grip in the tips.

The practice in truth is to create a physical response in the palm of the hand. You don't truly want the middle of your palm on the mat (almost think of a tiny tent being made in the middle of your hand), because this can dump too much weight in the wrists and cause injury and pain. When you push a little on your finger prints, you will notice that the joints at the base of your fingers (like your ball joints on the bottom of your feet) will press more deeply into your mat, lifting the center, and taking a bit of pressure off the base of the palm (because now your body weight is at the base of the fingers).

I hope that helps, it takes some practice!
